purpose: Debunk common myths about cloud computing.
title: Let's debunk some common myths around cloud

tables.title: Myths vs Realities
tables.description: A comparison of myths and realities about cloud.

cells: Moving apps to cloud increases total cost of ownership.
Apps can be cheaper in the cloud if appropriately remediated, if costs are attributed properly, and if redundant costs are taken out.
You move to the cloud to reduce IT costs.
You may get IT costs to break even, but the value that comes from the speed, agility, innovation, and scalability swamps potential IT cost reductions.
The security I can set up and control in my own data centers is superior to the security on cloud.
Almost all off-premises vulnerabilities result from misconfiguration; security as code is required to enable protection and agility.
Applications suffer latency on public cloud.
Current architectural choices (eg, backhauling) can increase latency off-premises, but different choices yield better results.
Moving to cloud eliminates the need for an infrastructure organization.
While smaller, an effective infrastructure organization is even more important off-premises but requires an agile, product-based model.
The most effective way to transition to cloud is to focus either on applications or on entire data centers.
Banks have different paths to success.
To move to cloud, you must either lift and shift applications as they are today or refactor them entirely.
A range of options exist between lift-and-shift and complete refactoring, with optimized infrastructure as a service (IaaS) and containerization potentially attractive.
